awd_titl_txt: Computational Prediction of Enantioselectivity in Metal-Catalyzed Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry is funding the project "Computational Prediction of Enantioselectivity in Metal-Catalyzed Reactions" in the groups of Olaf Wiest and Paul Helquist at the University of Notre Dame. The project develops, validates, and applies computational methods for the prediction of stereoselectivity (preferential formation of one arrangement of atoms in space over other possibilities in a molecule) and regioselectivity (preferential formation of new bonds at specific positions of a molecule over other possible positions). The ability to correctly predict reaction selectivity in transition metal catalysis has a broad impact in the pharmaceutical and fine chemicals industry. Highly selective reactions are needed to produce safer, more effective, and lower cost drugs. The project provides multi-disciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students that emphasizes the close connection between computational and experimental approaches and their application to practical problems. 

The prediction method involves five steps: (i) calculation of the pertinent transition structures for the targeted reactions using electronic structure methods, (ii) parameterization and validation of ground- and transition state force fields (TSFF) using quantum-guided molecular mechanics (Q2MM), (iii) calculation of the free energy difference of the relevant diastereomeric transition structures using full Monte Carlo conformational sampling at the transition state with the TSFF, (iv) use of the force fields for rapid prediction of enantioselectivities for virtual ligand libraries, and (v) selection and experimental evaluation of top ligand candidates for validation. The methods are used for a variety of reactions of importance in synthetic organic chemistry, including: (i) Mukaiyama aldol condensations, (ii) Heck arylations, (iii) 1,4-addition of organoboron compounds to unsaturated carbonyls, and (iv) imine reductions. The TSFFs and the Q2MM code is available to the scientific community via Github.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objectives of this research program were met with a high level of success. The main goals were the development of new computational methods to predict the stereochemical selectivities of reactions that are catalyzed by chiral transition metal complexes for the production of chiral compounds. One indication of the importance of such methods is that the majority of the largest selling pharmaceutical products are chiral molecules for which the desired biological activity is most often closely tied to having a specific stereochemical structure or, more explicitly, a particular enantiomer. In the past, the selection of catalysts to obtain the desired compounds was done by costly and time-consuming empirical trial-and-error experimental screening methods in academic or industrial laboratories. A reliable method that would predict reaction outcomes in advance would greatly facilitate and streamline the selection of optimum catalysts. The principal method that was developed in this project was the quantum-guided molecular mechanics (Q2MM) tool. It was greatly refined from its earlier forms, and an automated procedure (CatVS) was developed for virtual screening of large collections or libraries of potential catalysts. CatVS makes this approach to catalyst selection more accessible to chemists without significant prior experience with advanced computational methods. These aspects of the project were done in collaboration with Professor Per-Ola Norrby, the original inventor of Q2MM. He has spent several years in academic positions at three universities in Europe and is now on the research staff of the AstraZeneca pharmaceutical company in Sweden.

These computational tools have been shown to be the most successful such methods developed to date and have been shown to be applicable to a broad range of types of reactions of general utility to scientists and to chemical or pharmaceutical manufacturers. These reactions include enantioselective hydrogenation of alkenes, ketones, and imines, Heck-type alkenylation reactions, alkene dihydroxylations, conjugate addition reactions of unsaturated ketones, and cyclization reactions forming polycyclic ethers. The computational work was combined with parallel experimental studies involving the synthesis of catalysts, the validation of their performance in reactions, and the synthesis of compounds of bio-organic interest as mechanistic probe molecules or as potential therapeutic agents, especially for rare, genetic diseases.

The results of this research have been disseminated to the broader scientific community. It has been the subject of 13 papers published in major scientific journals, 3 presentations at chemistry conferences, and seminars at other universities. In addition, we have made the computational codes available free of charge via github on the Internet. These methods have been adopted for use by the process development department of two of the world?s largest pharmaceutical companies and by research groups at several other universities. In addition to publications, we continue to support these groups by hand-on training in Q2Mm and CatVS

As contributions to the scientific work force, this research program has provided training in modern computational and experimental methods to a total of 17 students, including 6 undergraduate students, 11 graduate students, 5 female students, 12 male students, and 4 underrepresented minority students. Of these students, 5 have now received their B.Sc. degrees and have matriculated in Ph.D. or M.D. programs at other universities, and  6 have received their Ph.D. degrees and have taken academic or industrial positions. The remaining 6 students are continuing their degree studies currently. In addition to the computational and experimental work, this project has provided training to students in proper safety protocols in research, scientific writing, presentation of research results, and critical assessment of the scientific literature. Two  of these students also gained additional research experience through international industrial internships at Astra Zeneca in Sweden, continuing a long-standing tradition in the group of the PIs. Finally both PIs continued their service to the scientific and broader communities through lectures, editorships and the organization of the Siemens Competition.
